text:
Great. So I'll be talking today about
the history of CryptoArt. But before I get in, just a
quick background about me.

So as mentioned, I was one of
the co-founders of the Stanford Blockchain Club. Back then, it was probably
only a dozen of us.

And it's pretty crazy to
see how the club has grown, significantly since
now there's a class. So it's really good to be back.

I got into crypto I
guess my freshman year. I wrote my freshman PWR
paper-- if you're an undergrad,

you know what PWR is. So I wrote my freshman
PWR paper on Ethereum. This is like right
when Ethereum launched.

And since then, since college,
I have one confirmation which

is a $130 million seed fund. We've made a lot of
big NFT investments,

such as leading the seed
round of OpenSea in 2018. We also have an NFT fund now.

So not only do we
invest in early stage projects in the crypto space,
we also buy jpegs and artworks

directly. And lastly, I just
want to mention that I built a personal website
called cryptoart.io, which

it basically aggregates
all the NFT art sales across different
marketplaces. So it's really cool when artists
can see all of their sales
in one place. So without further ado--

I guess, before
we get into NFTs, I just kind of want
to talk about how digital artists make money.

So you can be an artist that
you don't create drawings

or paintings, but you just have
a large Instagram portfolio and you have hundreds of
thousands of followers.

And how do you make a
living as a digital artist? And before NFTs, there were
a couple ways to do so.

The first one, obviously,
is to sell prints. So this is an artist
named Etiene Crauss.

And selling prints is kind
of like selling posters. You might sell them for like
a couple hundred dollars each.

But these prints, they never
garnered a lot of money because they're--

you're selling posters. So you're only selling
copies of the artworks, rather than the original
authentic one, which

is what the collector wants. So it's like selling
a poster of the Mona Lisa versus the actual
Mona Lisa itself.

One is worth much
more than the other. And the other way that
artists make money

is through commissions. And this can range from
things like creating album art

for musicians. So there are a lot of musicians
that create a new album. They need an artist to
design the album art.

And they'll earn like probably
like $500 to a couple thousand for designing the album art.

And if you're a really
well-established artist or design studio, then
you can get bigger clients like Fortune 500 companies.

This is one of my favorite
interior design studios called Six N. Five. And in 2019, they had a really
big collaboration with Microsoft

to design all the wallpaper
art for the Microsoft Surface.

And these big design
gigs can range from like a couple thousand
dollars to tens of thousands

of dollars. So all in all,
artists are usually making money from selling
prints or doing commissions.

But what I really
want to get into is that NFTs are a new business
model for digital artists.

So not only do they make money
from selling prints and doing commissions, they can also sell
individual artworks, like how

you would sell paintings. So it kind of revolutionizes
the whole way creators

make money in this
digital world is before, we were kind of in
this patronage business model

where you make money from
having a patron like Microsoft. And then, now, you can
be an independent creator

where you sell an
Instagram photo as an NFT. And that can be worth lots, like
thousands, tens of thousands

of dollars. And NFTs solves like
the "right click, save as" problem that
people talk about for jpegs

because collectors know this
is the original version that was minted from the artist. And that's the one that's
worth a lot of money.

So I want to talk a bit
about the early NFT history

before CryptoArt. So this is kind of not
really talked about much.

But you know CryptoPunks
wasn't the very first NFT. There were a lot
of attempts at NFTs

before that, starting
back with Bitcoin. So Colored Coins was a thing
in Bitcoin in the early days.

Basically, you would trace a
Bitcoin from when it was minted,

like in the genesis
block, and make these Bitcoin nonfungible,
where certain Bitcoin are

worth more than
others because they came from-- they were
minted in certain ways, came from certain addresses. And that was kind
of the first attempt

at making Bitcoin
nonfungible and applying that concept to NFTs. And then, we have a
slew of other projects,

starting with
Counterparty, which is a Bitcoin sidechain that
enabled NFT functionalities.

And you had early projects
built on Counterparty, like Spells of Genesis, More
Trading Cards, Rare Pepes.

And Rare Pepes eventually
migrated from Bitcoin to Ethereum. So Rare Pepes was really one
of the first NFT projects
that preceded CryptoPunks.

And then, the whole
space really started-- well, really, people
think of CryptoPunks

as like the first
brand name NFT project. And that started
back in June 2017.

And this was at the
time when the ERC-721. Standard wasn't invented
it was still ERC-20.

So it was this hacky
way of having NFTS in a fungible-- it was using
the fungible token standard.

And if you aren't
familiar with CryptoPunks, it's basically a collection of
10,000 profile pictures, each

with different, unique character
traits in their avatars, some traits are more
rare than others.

Like alien punks,
zombie punks, ape punks are worth like much
more than others

because there's only a
very few number of those.

And then, we get
to January 2018.

And this is when the ERC-721
standard was finally invented. And this is kind of the
first big NFT standard.

And it was invented
by Dapper Labs, which is the company
behind CryptoKitties. So like I said
before, before 721,

all these NFT
projects were trying to use hacky ways of
creating fungible tokens,

like ethereum ICO tokens,
and using those for NFTS. But now, there's finally
a standard for NFTs.

And that's really kicked
off a lot of new projects building on the standard.

So now, we went through
the early NFT history. Let's talk a bit
about CryptoArt.

So CryptoArt is really
a subsector of NFTs. And a lot of people
kind of lump everything

that's NFT that
has to do with art. But there's a lot more
to NFTs that's just art. There's music.

There's gaming. There's like IP rights. And CryptoArt was like really
one of the first verticals

within NFTs, one
of the first niches that really kind of got
a big community early on.

So the artist-- sorry, the
collector Jason Bailey, who goes by Artnome, he
was really the first person

to talk about CryptoArt. And he even coined the term. And on the screen here, this
is the formal definition

of CryptoArt. But Jason Bailey
is a guy who's-- he's been collecting
super early.

He was also into kind
of traditional art before he got into
crypto and was writing

a lot about the potential
of blockchain tech and how that can be
used in the art world.

So he coined the term CryptoArt. And shortly thereafter, the
first CryptoArt platform

emerged, which was SuperRare.  So around April, that's when
the first piece of CryptoArt

got minted. And it's called AI
Generated Nude Portrait. The artist is an artist
named Robbie Barrat,

who goes by videodrome. Robbie Barrat actually used to
live right next to Stanford. I think he was like somewhere
in Palo Alto, Menlo Park.

He now moved to Amsterdam. But he was this
early AI artist who

was experimenting with a lot
of different things, came across SuperRare, decided to
mint one of his GAN art pieces.

And GAN stands for "generative
adversarial networks." So it's really popular
now with stable diffusion.

But basically, you take you
take an image that's a seed. You feed it through
the AI algorithm.

And you see what are
the intermediate steps. And then, you take that and
then use that as your artwork.

So he goes like four or
five years to this trend before stable diffusion
and the current OpenAI hype

made it really cool. So back in April
of 2018, he sold

this piece for 0.46 ETH,
which at the time was $177.

So that was a big
deal at the time because it showed that
people were willing to pay at least something for NFTs.

But fast forward a few
years later, and then we, 1confirmation, we actually
bought this artwork.

We bought it for 100 ETH,
which was $112k at the time. So that's a 217x increase
from the initial sale price.

So videodrome, Robbie
Barrat-- sorry, Artnome got a pretty big windfall from
that, not only from that sale,

but also all the
intermediary collectors that the piece
changed hands through.

And I think this
will be kind of one of the pioneering pieces in
art history textbooks, just

for the fact that it was
the first piece of CryptoArt minted on chain.

And there's actually another
fun story in the early CryptoArt history. So there's the story
of the "Lost Robbies."

So this was around,
I think June, July-- July 2018. So this was at a
conference in London

where SuperRare
was talking about-- they were kind of pitching
Christie's and like all

of these boomer traditional art
collectors about the promise of NFTs and CryptoArt. And obviously, the 300 attendees
that attended most of them

didn't really get it. And as part of
their presentation, they had these gift bags
where there was a QR code.

And you could scan it to
claim a piece of Robbie Barrat CryptoArt. And obviously, most
people, when you pick up

these QR codes in gift
bags from conferences, you just throw them
away immediately. But the lucky 12
people who actually did

claim their Robbie
Barrats, those pieces sell for six figures today.

And since all of the others
haven't been claimed, it's highly likely that the
remaining 288 are lost forever.

So in CryptoArt lore, those
are called the "Lost Robbies." And you can see here,
in this tweet, a lot

of these different pieces. Those are different variations
of the "Lost Robbies" that are lost forever.

So that's just a kind of fun
anecdote from the early history.

And another piece of
early CryptoArt history is this artist named XCOPY.

So the 5th to 16th artworks
minted on SuperRare were all by XCOPY.

And all 12 of these pieces,
they're worth a lot today

because one of the features
of the blockchain is it timestamps when NFTS--

or when any transaction happens. And another beauty
of the blockchain is that it's an
immutable ledger,

so you can't go back in history
and change those timestamps. And that's the
advantage that SuperRare

and these early
artists have is they have the advantage
of being first. So they always have
this good narrative

that we're first to
this industry, here's the proof on the
on the blockchain that we minted these
artworks early.

And no other new artists
can replicate this because we came here first. So each of these
pieces will sell

for about six to seven figures. And these are 12 of the most
valuable pieces of CryptoArt

just because they were some of
the very first pieces minted on chain.

And that also ties to this
point, which is the second value prop of why CryptoArt matters,
why having a blockchain

is powerful, is the blockchain
provides provenance. And I talked a bit
about the timestamping.

The other thing is just
being able to trace ownership from the artist through all
of the series of collectors,

as they keep reselling the
pieces, to who the current owner is. And you'd be surprised
how art fraud is actually

a really big problem in
the traditional art world, especially when you have
artworks that are kind of hidden

in this Swiss warehouse that
are used for money laundering, for tax evasion.

And it's just changing
hands constantly through a series of paperworks. But no one can really
tell exactly which hands

this artwork changed through. And there isn't really a
ledger that traces the history,

versus having a blockchain,
it's all transparent. You can see who exactly the
artists did the primary sale,

how much all the subsequent
secondary sales are, and who the current
collector is.

And the other part that
I talked about a bit is because of these immutable
timestamps that the blockchain

provides, it creates something
known as the Lindy Effect, which

is basically the notion that the
longer something's been around, the more valuable it is
and the more secure it is.

And this is why the
early artists' pieces are valuable because they
were first to the category

and they've been
around for a long time. And this is also why
people talk about NFTs

minted on other blockchains
like Solana or Tezos. And this is why ethereum NFTs
command a premium to Solana

and Tezos NFTs is because
ethereum was first and there's a stronger
security guarantee. And that's why
they're more valuable.

And you can also say the same
thing with other marketplaces. An artist will mint NFTs across
lots of different marketplaces.

Not just SuperRare,
but there's also Foundation, Nifty Gateway,
KnownOrigin, MakersPlace,

the list goes on. But the reason why
the SuperRare NFTs will sell for more compared
to all the other marketplaces

is because SuperRare was first. It has this premium brand. And artists want to get curated,
want to get listed on SuperRare.

And collectors will pay a
premium for a SuperRare NFT. And this all ties
to the Lindy Effect.

And the last thing I'll say
about why the blockchain matters

for art is
programmatic royalties. So earlier, why I talked
about this Robbie Barrat

piece that sold for $177
in the primary sale--

because of the SuperRare
artist royalty system, Robbie Barrat actually
earned roughly $10,000

because you can have an
artist that becomes super big and their collectors will be
able to flip or resell something

for much more down the road. But the artist capture--
in the traditional art world, the artist captures
none of that value.

But now, with artist
royalties, the artist gets to capture the value of
their artworks appreciating,

not just the collector. And this is really beneficial
for early SuperRare artists.

I talked about Robbie Barrat. XCOPY, one of the other
early SuperRare artists,

he's earning a lot
more from royalties because, back in the early days,
these pieces were only selling

for a couple hundred dollars. And now, from
artist's royalties, they're making 10 to 100
times more than that, just
from the royalties alone.

So we talked a bit about fine
art, which fine art was really the first subgenre of
CryptoArt that really emerged.

But kind of in parallel, there
was another genre of CryptoArt called "generative art."

So first, what exactly
is generative art? So it's a class of
digital art where

artists use a computer
to introduce randomness as a part of the
creation process.

And here's a quote
from Snowfro, who's the founder of Art Blocks, who
talks about generative art, how

this is revolutionary because
it enables a new art form that wasn't possible before.

So the first piece of
generative art was-- or the first generative
art collection

created in April 2019,
called Autoglyphs. And this was created by the same
team that created CryptoPunks.

Basically, it's an
edition of 512 pieces created by smart contract code.

And I'll get into
the code in a bit. But basically, you seed it
with a random number generator.

And then, you hash it to
create some random value. And then, based
on the value, you

give it instructions-- like
kind of a bunch of if statements as you loop through
the hash values.

And that will tell
the code to print out

certain ASCII characters. And then, when you
piece that together, you create this entire artwork,
which is called an "Autoglyph."

And this is kind
of the code that I was talking about earlier. So you pass in the function.

You pass in the seed. You pass an ID, which
converts to the seed. And the seed is created through
entropy from the blockchain.

So that can be things like
block number, timestamp. And that entropy is used to
create a random hash value.

And then, from the
hash value, in kind of the bottom half
of the code, you see a bunch of if statements.

And through each if statement,
it concatenates a piece of ASCII

based on what the hex value is. And then, once you iterate
through all of these characters,

and that's how you create
the entire Autoglyph.

So Autoglyphs was the first
generative art project. But generative art
didn't really take off

until a project called
Art Blocks came along. And this was late 2020.

So Art Blocks was founded
by Erick Calderon, who's also known as Snowfro.

So Erick was actually
a prolific artist before he got into crypto and
blockchains and generative art.

And he's been doing this off
chain using other techniques. And he decided, why don't I
bring this technique on chain

and create this art
platform called Art Blocks? And since he's an
artist himself,

he minted the very first
Art Blocks collection, called Chromie Squiggles. So as you can see
here, there's a lot

of different variations
of squiggles, each with different
rarity characteristics.

And as these are minted,
it's using the entropy of the blockchain to decide--

And this is all randomly
generated by the blockchain. And it's a unique
art form enabled

by the blockchain because
of the entropy associated.

So Chromie Squiggles was like
the first Art Blocks project. And since then, there's been a
couple 100 Art Blocks projects.

And two of the most notable
ones are Ringers and Fidenza. So Ringers was created by
Dmitri Cherniak, who was also

another prolific generative
artist before NFTs and crypto came along.

And as you can see here,
it's basically a bunch of pegs and lines and colors.

And the orientation of these
pegs and lines and colors is created by entropy,
which certain Ringers are

worth more than others
because they're more rare. And Fidenza is similarly
another project

by Tyler Hobbs, who's a big,
prolific generative artist.

And it's a series of tiles
created through entropy. And I think the floor
price now for "Ringers"

is around 40 ETH ish. And then, for "Fidenza,"
it's like around 70 ETH.

So like these were only-- I think they were like sub 1 ETH
at the time they were minted.

And since then, collectors
see generative art as a valuable store of value.

And that's why the floor price
has increased by so much.

And so we had these early art
projects like with SuperRare,

Art Blocks, Autoglyphs,
CryptoPunks. But art was still pretty--

CryptoArt was still pretty
confined to crypto natives. Like only people who really
understood the value of crypto

really understood it, believed
in the potential of CryptoArt. And CryptoArt didn't
really go mainstream

until this guy came along. And this guy's name
is Beeple, who's--

well, "Beeple" is a
kind of alias name. But his real name
is Mike Winkelmann. And he's actually the first
very-well-known artist outside

of crypto to finally learn
what NFTs are and decide to mint something in crypto.

So even before he got
into NFTs, he already had over a million
Instagram followers.

And his kind of claim
to fame is he minted-- he's one of the most
prolific VFX artists.

So what that is-- basically,
it stands for "visual effects." Used a piece of software
called "Cinema 4D."

And that's it's kind
of like Photoshop-ish. But you create all these 3D
graphics with different models,

like figurines, heads. You can see in the screenshot
in the bottom-right corner

of the photo of
him in the process of creating a piece of artwork. And he started these
Everydays back in 2007,

where he would create a new
piece of artwork every day since 2007. And he hasn't
missed a single day.

And it's actually pretty
crazy how he's kept this up. And you can see
artworks that he's

created during
certain anniversaries, like when his daughter was
born, when he was sick.

But even throughout all
these different milestones in his life, he's
still never missed

a day of creating artwork. So that's kind of
his claim to fame. So he was really famous for
creating this Everydays series.

But he was never really
able to monetize that. It was like, he had
created a piece of artwork,

posted it on Instagram, and
he would get a big Instagram following. But no one was really
paying for that.

So instead, he had to
kind of make a living through doing other jobs,
like creating graphics

for concert visuals. So like when a big DJ
or EDM artist tours,

they need big concert
visuals behind them. And he would create
those visuals. Or he would also do other
commissioned artworks

for clients. That was also another way that
digital artists during the time

made a living. And that all changed when
he decided to mint NFTs.

So it was back in October 2020
where Beeple learned about NFTs

and minted his very first
piece, which is a piece called "Politics is Bullshit."

And this is a piece
mentioned on Nifty Gateway. It was only edition of 100.

And as kind of a joke, he
set the mint price to $1. So obviously, they got sold
out in less than a second.

And if you're one of
the lucky 100 people that was able to snag this
piece, today it'd be worth--

the floor price right now is 85
ETH, which is about $130,000. So that's a pretty good return
for being super fast at clicking

the Buy button. And I guess I also want to talk
about Nifty Gateway, where--

to date, I've talked
about one of one arts, like on SuperRare, where
it's only artists selling

one piece or a
collection of like say 10,000 generative pieces. But Nifty Gateway
popularized a new way

of artists selling
works, which are called "editions" and "open editions."

So edition can be, say, an
edition of 5 or edition of 100.

And it's the same jpeg. But that way, you have
5 different collectors

or 100 different collectors
who can collect your piece. And that helps an artist
get more buy in and a bigger

community of collectors. And there's also something
called "open editions," which is unlimited mints.

So an artist will say, OK,
for the next 10 minutes,

anyone can make my piece. And after that,
it's done forever.

And that was a really
popular way for a bunch, like thousands, of collectors
to get a really cheap piece

from their favorite
artist without having to pay a lot to buy a 1 of 1.

So after that
October sale, Beeple did a couple more drops,
a mix of additions,

1 of 1s, open additions. But things didn't really get
super crazy until march 2021.

And this is when
Beeple did the auction at Christie's through an art
platform called MakersPlace.

And this is a collage of the
first 5,000 Everydays pieces.

So, like I said earlier, Beeples
had created a new piece of art from 2007 all the way to 2021
without missing a single day.

And this is a collage of every
single one of those artworks. And he decided to auction
this off at Christie's.

And there was a lot of
press coverage at the time because there was already
a bidding war going on.

And I was watching this live. And it was crazy-- as
the auction was closing,

the bids jumped from
like a couple million. And then, it went
to like $20 million. And then, it went
to $50 million.

And then, finally, a
collector paid $69 million for this piece of artwork.

And immediately, that kind of
blew up the entire art world.

It got on the front page of
like every single newspaper. And this is also the
sixth-highest artwork sale

of all time by a living artist. And Beeple's, in the kind of in
the same names as these legends

like Jasper Johns, Damien Hirst,
you could say Jeff Koons-- these very, very
big-name artists

in the traditional art world. And he's up there
with all of them. And the last thing I'll say is,
the collector name is Metakovan.

He's an Indian
crypto billionaire. And he's been collecting
art for a very long time.

He not only owns this one piece. But he also owns all
of Beeple's 1 of 1s.

So he's the largest Beeple
collector, also has an NFT fund. And he's not looking
to sell this.

So he's just kind
of patiently waiting and thinks that this is a
historical piece of art.

Did you raise your hand? Yeah. I'm just curious. I have a question of what would
be the motivation for someone

to buy this? Can you repeat the question? Yeah. So the question is like, what's
the motivation for someone

to buy this? Well, if you think it's a
piece of like art history significance, then you would
pay like a stupidly high price

because you would think that
in like 50 years from now, it will be worth even more. And that's also how the
traditional art world

works is the most expensive,
the most valuable things are worth paying
up a lot of money

for because those
are the ones that are going to be worth even more. So basically, if
you bought a Picasso

or you bought an Andy
Warhol like 50 years ago, those are the ones
that are worth.

People at the time
kind of laughed at you if you paid those prices. But those are the pieces
that accumulated value,

rather than other artists. So that's kind of, I think,
what he's thinking here, where Beeple is going
to be the Andy Warhol

of the internet generation. And that's why it's worth
paying a lot for this because this is going
to end up in museums.

This is going to end up
in art history textbooks 30 to 50 years from now.

Cool. So this sale happened. And as I said, CryptoArt
becomes mainstream.

So it's on the headlines
of New York Times. I know Beeple appears on
Joe Rogan, on Jimmy Fallon.

Basically, he turns
into a celebrity overnight because
this artist that was kind of living a semi
paycheck-to-paycheck,

but a very modest
life just doing commissions for clients all of
a sudden pockets $69 million from one sale.

And that's completely
changed his life and really legitimizes the
entire CryptoArt, NFT space.

So really, after that, that was
a turning point for CryptoArt.

So I want to continue
with some data. So this is kind of a volume
graph of CryptoArt sales.

And you can see the first
blip was in March 2021, which was when Beeple did that sale.

And then, the next blip, I
think, was in August 2021. That's when Art
Blocks went crazy. That was the generative art
platform I talked about earlier.

And that's when the floor
price of Ringers, Fidenzas, all of those generative
art pieces shot up

from like sub 1 ETH to 40, 60
ETH or kind of absurd amounts

because collectors saw
those as super valuable. Obviously, it's come
down since because there

was a lot of speculative
froth at the time. But as you can see, as
the volumes plateau,

where it bottoms out is higher
than like the previous-- before CryptoArt
really became a thing.

And that's always
healthy because as long as the trough is higher
than the previous peak,

it kind of mirrors the history
of cryptocurrency cycles, where each boom is higher
than the previous bust

and so on and so forth,
as this space kind of has these speculative frenzies,
but over the long run,

it legitimizes. And the last thing
I want to say is, the total market
cap of CryptoArt

is only 0.2% of the total
market cap of cryptocurrencies. And the reason we, as a fund,
we're making a big bet in NFTs

is we think that percentage
is going to grow significantly over time, that CryptoArt, NFTs
is going to disrupt culture.

And the total market
cap of culture is much, much bigger than--

of nonfungible assets is much,
much bigger than total market cap of fungible assets.

And the other thing I
want to talk about this-- this is a screenshot from
my website, cryptoart.io.

But you can see who are
the top 10 artists here. So you have Pak as number 1.

Beeple is number 2. Snowfro, who's the founder
of Art Blocks, is number 3. You have Tyler Hobbs,
XCOPY, Dmitri Cherniak.

These are some of the artists
that I've mentioned earlier. And you can see the total
value of their artworks are in the tens of millions
to hundreds of millions.

And this kind of all
came out of nowhere in just a couple of years,
where in traditional art world,

these would be pretty
absurd numbers. But it shows how there's a lot
of collector demand, interest

in CryptoArt. And that's why the total
value of these artworks are worth how much
they're worth.

So we kind of talked
about the past and the present of CryptoArt.

So I just want to talk a bit
about the future of CryptoArt. So kind of my first prediction
for what's going to happen

is traditional art
institutions are going to start curating
CryptoArt collections

and feature them in
museums and in galleries.
